column14: How did you hear about this program?
column15: Please tell us why you are interested; what you hope to get out of your participation in this program.
column16: What language do you use for casual conversation? (Primary language spoken at home.)
column17: What type of tea do you prefer?
column18: Tell us about you! Include any interests that you think will help us make a better match with your Tea-Mate.
column19: If you are a college student, what college are you attending?
column20: Your preferred pronouns (for example: she/her, he/him, they/them).
column21: Please confirm that you agree to PRIORITIZE a weekly conversation with your Tea-Mate for 12 weeks. (It's important for us to know that your Tea-Mate can count on you!)
column22: Please tell us about any special circumstances or limitations, physical or otherwise, that may prevent you from fully engaging in this Community.
column23: Please confirm that you have read and agree with the disclaimer below.

column14: My roommate participated last semester and loved it! She kept telling me about the amazing conversations she had with her tea-mate and encouraged me to sign up.
column15: I grew up really close with my grandparents who passed away during COVID, and I miss having those cross-generational conversations. They always had such interesting perspectives on life and I learned so much from them. I am studying engineering which is pretty male-dominated and technical, so I would love to have meaningful conversations outside my usual bubble. Plus, I am terrible at keeping in touch with people and having a scheduled weekly call would help me be more intentional about connecting with others.
column16: English, but I also speak Gujarati with my parents when I call them
column17: Chai! Or any black tea really
column18: I am a junior studying mechanical engineering at UConn. I am part of the robotics club and we compete in regional competitions. Outside of school, I love hiking (did the Appalachian Trail last summer!), cooking (especially trying recipes from different cultures), and playing guitar. I am also really into sustainability and environmental issues. I volunteer with the campus food pantry and I am trying to reduce my own carbon footprint. I am generally an optimistic person but can be a bit shy at first.
column22: None that I can think of. My schedule is pretty flexible.

column14: I saw a flyer at the library and thought it sounded like a wonderful opportunity.
column15: Since retiring three years ago, I find myself with more time on my hands and missing the daily interactions I had at work. My children live out of state and while we talk regularly, they are busy with their own lives. I think it would be enriching to connect with a younger person and learn about what life is like for them today. The world has changed so much! I am also curious about what challenges young people face now compared to what I experienced.
column18: I am a retired accountant who now spends my time gardening, reading mystery novels, and spoiling my two grandchildren when they visit. I was married for 42 years before my wife passed. I enjoy classical music and used to play the violin in a community orchestra. I am politically engaged and read the news every morning. I like discussing current events, history, and philosophy. I consider myself a lifelong learner and I am always curious about new topics.
column23: Yes, I have read and agree

column15: Honestly, I spend way too much time on my phone and scrolling social media. I want to have real, meaningful conversations with someone from a different generation. I think it would help me be more present and less anxious about the future. My great-aunt was my favorite person to talk to and she passed away last year, so I am hoping to find that kind of connection again.
column18: I am a sophomore at Yale studying comparative literature. I love reading (currently going through all of Toni Morrison novels), writing poetry, and going to coffee shops to people-watch. I am on the university newspaper as an arts writer. I grew up in a small town and coming to New Haven was a big adjustment. I am interested in social justice, LGBTQ+ issues, and mental health awareness. In my free time I like watching foreign films, going to museums, and trying new restaurants. I am also learning to crochet!
column22: I have a pretty busy schedule with classes and work-study, but I can always make time for a weekly call. Evenings or weekends work best for me.

column14: My neighbor who is also a member told me all about it. She said it really brightened her week.
column15: I participated once before about five years ago and absolutely loved it. My tea-mate and I had such fascinating discussions about everything from politics to cooking to travel. We are still Facebook friends! Now that I am fully retired and my husband passed away two years ago, I find myself wanting more social connection. This program is perfect because it is structured but also flexible, and I love the idea of being paired with someone I might not otherwise meet.
column17: I like herbal teas, chamomile is my favorite
column18: I grew up in Ireland and moved to the States in 1975 when I married. I raised four children and worked as a nurse for 40 years before retiring. Now I volunteer at a hospice twice a week and I find it very meaningful work. I love gardening - I have a vegetable garden and grow my own tomatoes, beans, and herbs. I am active in my church community. I enjoy walking, though my knees are not what they used to be! I love sharing stories and I am a good listener. I believe in the importance of community and helping others.
column22: I have some hearing loss so speaking clearly and maybe a bit louder would be helpful. Otherwise no limitations.

column15: I am a sociology major interested in aging and social isolation. This seemed like a great way to learn firsthand about intergenerational relationships while also making a genuine connection. I am also interested in oral history and would love to hear stories from someone who lived through different historical moments. Plus I think it will help me become a better listener.
column18: I am a senior at Wesleyan double majoring in sociology and education. After graduation I want to teach high school social studies. I play on the club volleyball team and I love being active - yoga, running, swimming. I am passionate about educational equity and I tutor middle schoolers in math. I grew up in a big family (youngest of five!) so I am used to lively conversations and different perspectives. I like trying new things and am pretty open-minded. I also love cooking big meals for friends.

column14: The Hartford Courant had an article about the program a few months ago. I cut it out and kept it on my fridge!
column15: I moved to Connecticut six months ago to be closer to my daughter and do not know many people in the area yet. I thought this would be a lovely way to meet someone new and have something to look forward to each week. I have always enjoyed talking with young people - they keep me on my toes and introduce me to new ideas. I used to volunteer as a mentor at my local high school before I moved.
column16: English, though I learned Yiddish as a child
column17: Black tea with milk and honey
column18: I spent my career in sales and marketing for a pharmaceutical company. I have always been a people person and I genuinely enjoy hearing about others lives and experiences. Since retiring, I have taken up watercolor painting (I am not very good but I enjoy it!) and I go to a weekly art class. I like jazz music, going to the theater, and traveling when I can. My wife and I just took up ballroom dancing. I try to stay physically active with daily walks and swimming at the Y. I have a good sense of humor and do not take myself too seriously.
column23: I have read and agree with the disclaimer

column14: Word of mouth - my advisor suggested I check it out
column15: My grandmother lives in Puerto Rico and I only see her once a year. I really miss having an older person in my life to talk to about important decisions and just life in general. I am the first person in my family to go to college and sometimes I feel like I do not have anyone who really understands what I am going through. I hope my tea-mate can offer some wisdom and perspective, and maybe I can offer a fresh perspective too!
column16: Spanish and English - I am bilingual
column18: I am a first-generation college student at Trinity studying psychology with hopes of becoming a therapist. I work part-time at a daycare which I love - kids are so honest and funny! I am really interested in understanding how people think and what motivates them. I enjoy painting, listening to podcasts (true crime and self-improvement mostly), and spending time outdoors. I am from a small town in Connecticut and still adjusting to city life. I value deep conversations and authentic connections. I am also really interested in different cultures and perspectives.
column22: I work on weekends sometimes at my part-time job, so weekday evenings would be best for me.

column14: I participated several years ago and stayed in touch with my tea-mate. We still email! I would love to meet someone new this time.
column15: After my stroke last year, I have been more homebound than I would like. I still have my mind and love good conversation, but it is harder to get out and about. This program seems perfect because it is over the phone so I do not have to worry about mobility issues. I taught high school English for 35 years and I miss talking with young people about books and ideas and dreams for the future.
column18: I taught high school English for 35 years and absolutely loved it. Even though I am retired, I still think about books and literature constantly. I am in two book clubs! I had a stroke last year which affected my mobility, but my mind is as sharp as ever. I live alone but my daughter visits frequently. I love discussing books, politics, social issues, and what it means to live a good life. I consider myself progressive in my thinking despite my age. I miss the energy and curiosity of young people and the way they challenge assumptions.
column22: I had a stroke last year which affected my mobility, but I have full mental capacity and enjoy phone conversations. Sometimes I get a bit tired if calls go very long, but 30-45 minutes is perfect.

column14: TikTok video about intergenerational connection programs
column15: I feel like my generation is often misunderstood by older adults, and I want to bridge that gap. I also think I have a lot to learn from people with more life experience. I am trying to figure out what I want to do after graduation and having a sounding board would be really helpful. Plus during COVID I realized how isolated I can feel even when surrounded by people my own age.
column16: English and Korean with my family
column18: I am a first-year student at Central Connecticut State University studying computer science. I am really into gaming (both playing and the design aspects), anime, and technology. I built my own PC last year. I am also interested in music production and I make beats in my spare time. I am kind of introverted but once I get comfortable I open up. I am trying to get better at time management and not procrastinating. I think talking to someone with more life experience could help me figure out my priorities.

column14: My granddaughter showed me the website
column15: At my age, many of my friends have passed on or moved to be near their children. I do not want to sit around feeling sorry for myself! I have always believed in giving back to the community and I think sharing my experiences with a young person could be valuable for both of us. I also want to stay current and engaged with the world, and young people help me do that.
column17: Regular black tea with a little sugar
column18: I am 81 years old and I have lived quite a life! I was a teacher, then a librarian, and I have been volunteering at the historical society for the past 15 years. I love local history and genealogy - I have traced my family back six generations. I read voraciously, everything from biographies to science fiction. I live in a senior living community now and while there are activities here, I miss talking with young people. They ask questions I had not thought of! I may move slower these days but my mind is active and I have plenty of stories to share.
column22: My vision is not great anymore so I would not be able to do video calls, but phone calls are perfect.
